result_equations.equation: G = H - T S = U + P V - T S
dG = V dP - S dT + sum_i mu_i dN_i

explanation: Gibbs free energy is a thermodynamic potential that measures the maximum reversible work that can be performed by a system at constant temperature and pressure. It determines the direction of spontaneous processes: reactions proceed when ΔG < 0. This function is fundamental in chemistry, materials science, and phase transitions.

definitions.definition: Number of particles of species i.

assumptions.text: The system can exchange work and heat with surroundings but maintains constant temperature and pressure.
Reversible processes are considered for maximum work calculations.
The first law of thermodynamics applies with chemical work included.
The system is in quasi-static equilibrium during the process.

derivation.description: Start with the fundamental thermodynamic relation including chemical work.
derivation.equation: dU = T dS - P dV + sum_i mu_i dN_i

derivation.description: Define enthalpy as internal energy plus pressure-volume work.
Take the differential of enthalpy using the product rule.
derivation.equation: dH = dU + P dV + V dP

derivation.description: Substitute the first law to express dH in terms of entropy, pressure, and chemical potentials.
derivation.equation: dH = T dS + V dP + sum_i mu_i dN_i

derivation.description: Define Gibbs free energy as enthalpy minus temperature times entropy.
Take the differential of G using the product rule.
derivation.equation: dG = dH - T dS - S dT

derivation.description: Substitute the expression for dH to get the fundamental Gibbs relation.
derivation.equation: dG = V dP - S dT + sum_i mu_i dN_i

derivation.description: At equilibrium under constant T and P, the Gibbs free energy is minimized.
derivation.equation: At equilibrium: dG = 0 (at constant T, P)
